marker.label: Behind Milton Island
marker.comment: Milton Island offers good protection, especially if you can get into the bay that cuts into its East side.

marker.label: In the lee of Cedar Island
marker.comment: This is a pretty good place to anchor except for the nearby boat traffic, which tends to be significant on weekends and holidays

marker.label: Deep in Collins Bay
marker.comment: Deep into Collins Bay is okay in a North breeze, the further in the better. Shallow, muddy bottom. If things get bleak, dock at one of the marinas at the apex of the bay.

marker.label: Inner Harbour
marker.comment: Kingston's inner harbour is an OK anchorage in a North breeze but you'll need a bridge lift to get there if your vessel can't otherwise fit under the permanent span of the Lasalle Causeway.

marker.label: Tucked in under Horseshoe Island
marker.comment: Sheltered behind Horseshoe Island is a good spot. Very shallow, rocky bottom, still good if the wind shifts to almost any other direction.

marker.label: Tucked under Garden Island
marker.comment: This is a really great spot in a North or East breeze. Shallow, but the bottom (which you can probably see) is variable, either sand or, in the worst case, shelf rock. Keep an eye on it.

marker.label: Cassidy Bay
marker.comment: Very good anchorage in all circumstances except the prevailing direction, where it's fair to middlin'. Absolutely great bottom for anchoring. Careful of the shoal on the South-side of the mouth of the Bay when going-in.

marker.label: Navy Bay
marker.comment: Tucked between Royal Military College to the West and Fort Henry to the East, it's a picturesque and safe place in Northerly and Easterly breezes.
